title: 105_hr2985
content: Aliens are ineligible for visas and excluded from admission for nonpayment of child support. Aliens can be deemed inadmissible for nonpayment of child support exceeding $5,000, as per an amendment to the Immigration and Nationality Act. This amendment applies to visas issued 180 days after the enactment of the Act. The Immigration and Nationality Act has been amended to make aliens deportable for nonpayment of child support exceeding $5,000. Additionally, aliens may be ineligible for naturalization for failing to pay child support. Aliens may be ineligible for naturalization if they fail to pay child support as legally obligated. This amendment applies to naturalization applications filed 180 days after the enactment of the Act. Additionally, there is authorization to serve legal process in child support cases on certain arriving aliens. Immigration officers can serve legal process on alien applicants for admission regarding child support obligations, as defined by the Social Security Act. The amendment allows courts, agencies, or authorized officials to enforce child support obligations on alien applicants for admission to the United States. The amendment applies to aliens applying for admission 180 days after the enactment of the Act. The amendment authorizes the Immigration and Naturalization Service to request information on delinquent child support payments from the Secretary, aiding in determining if an alien is behind on child support.
